titleproper.value:
Guide to the Joseph A. McCarroll papers
                    <num>2015.001</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by John Zarrillo

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2015-03-25T09:52-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The papers document the life and work of Joseph A. McCarroll, an architect who worked in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Queens, New Jersey, Connecticut, and the West Coast, from around 1907 until 1958. Materials include photographs, architectural renderings, clippings, correspondence, resumes, and one scrapbook. In addition to his work as an architect, the papers also documents McCarroll's interest in amateur astronomy as a member of the Bergen County Amateur Astronomers Association.

p.value: Identification of item, date (if known); Joseph A. McCarroll papers, 2015.001, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

Joseph Allen McCarroll was born in Brooklyn, New York, on September 29, 1873 to William and Jennie Allen McCarroll. His father had emigrated from Ireland around 1870, and became a well known business man and civic activist. Joseph attended Cornell University, graduating in 1895 with a degree in architecture. He then worked in the family leather business for five years, before pursuing a career as an architect. He worked extensively in Brooklyn for 25 years (excepting a three year stint on the West Coast). He ran the McCarroll Construction Company from 1918 to 1925, specializing in residential homes and apartment buildings in Brooklyn. Later he was a principal partner in the firm of McCarroll, Murphy and Lehman, which specialized in the construction of schools and churches. He also worked for the firm of Thomas W. Lamb, which built large movie theaters. Later in life he served as Plan Examiner and Building Inspector for the Township of Teaneck, New Jersey, and in December 1941 became the Chief Civilian Architect at the United States Submarine Base at Groton, Connecticut. He continued to work as an architect until his retirement in 1958. McCarroll was also an avid amateur astronomer, and was a founding member and President of the Bergen County Amateur Astronomers Association. He died in Lawrenceville, New Jersey, in October 1970.
The papers also include family portraits, resumes, and professional correspondence. Annotations and clippings added by McCarroll's son, William H. McCarroll, also appear throughout the papers.

corpname.value: St. Peter Claver Church (Brooklyn, New York, N.Y.).
